The cathode of lithium -ion batteries contains a mixed oxide containing lithium and , at least, cobalt (LiCoO 2). At the end of their useful life, used batteries are considered waste electrical and electronic equipment. It is estimated that by 2020 the amount of discarded batteries could exceed 25 billion units, totaling 500,000 tons. In 2016 approximately 95% of these batterie s were disposed of , meaning they did not go through any recycling process. Final disposal in landfill s, stabilization or incineration is costly and also contaminates soil, water or air causing serious environmental impacts . On the other hand, such wastes are a potential secondary source for recovery of strategical elements for high technology applications such as cobalt and lithium. In most of the processes described in the literature leaching is performed using inorganic acids such as H 2SO 4, HNO 3 and HCl i n the presence of a reducing agent, often H 2O2. This study aims to evaluate the recovery of Co, Mn, Ni and Li from the ele ctroactive components of lithium -ion batteries, using formic acid as a leaching agent, and the recovery of leached metals by a combination of liquid -liquid extraction and precipitation methods . The sample is composed of a batch of batteries manufactured between 2010 and 2014 . It was characterized by X -ray fluorescence spectrometry (FRX).
